headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Georgia Voters Speak Out On Next Week's Senate Run; USA Men's Star Pulisic On Track To Play Tomorrow In Knockout Round; 2 Police Officers Rescue Child And Woman From Icy Pond. Aired 7:30-8a ET

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Yes. Well, that's interesting because let me -- I want to go to Lynn -- all right, Lynn? You are pro-life.LYNN WHITTENBURG, RETIRED SCHOOL TEACHER, SEN. WARNOCK AND GOV. KEMP SUPPORTER:  Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: You voted for Brian --

utterances.speaker: WHITTENBURG
utterances.sentences: I am pro.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. You voted for Brian Kemp for governor -- Republican governor. You appeared in an ad for Sen. Warnock about your decision to split your ballot in November -- voting for Warnock, a Democrat --

utterances.speaker: WHITTENBURG
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- Kemp, a Republican.Brian Kemp has campaigned for Herschel Walker. What do you think about that?

utterances.speaker: WHITTENBURG
utterances.sentences: Well, I pretty much voted Republican my whole life until the last six years. And I would say the biggest disqualifier for my voting for Herschel Walker that he was Trump-endorsed, and that had a big factor there.I was able to meet Rev. Warnock and I am very impressed with him. I feel like he will do a lot for the poor and he will do a lot for the low-income families, which might even encourage more women to be able to keep their babies because they're getting more help from the government. And I've been disappointed that the Republicans, who are pro-life, don't want to -- don't want to help that. So, I've kind of come to see my faith more in the light of not Republican or Democrat, but kind of looking at each issue, each election, and so forth, and weighing many factors.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. Well, it's interesting. You said because of -- because of Donald Trump -- of supporting Donald Trump. That is a big factor now. A lot of people are saying that it's time for the party to move on past Trump. Did that play into your decision?

utterances.speaker: WHITTENBURG
utterances.sentences: Yes. I felt like we've got to stomp that out -- I really did -- I feel like, especially after January 6. I had just had my knee replaced and I was sitting in front of the television all day and I couldn't believe what I was seeing. And most of my friends who still support Trump have been totally silent on that and haven't spoken out about that, and it really bothered me.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Lisa, I want to follow up with you because one of the previous folks talked about abortion. I know that you are a conservative. You have met Herschel Walker at campaign events. Are you at all troubled by the allegations against Herschel Walker that he paid for an abortion?

utterances.speaker: LISA KINNEMORE, EDUCATOR, HERSCHEL WALKER SUPPORTER
utterances.sentences: As far as a woman's right to choose, I support the life of the child from conception until natural death. The choice was made when the child was conceived.And as far as religion and Christianity, the Bible is clear about a child being formed in the wound, even from the beginning. And the life of the child is valuable. If a woman's life is in danger, that may be something different --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KINNEMORE
utterances.sentences: -- or -- you know, inside of incest or rape. But that is allowed in the law.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So the allegations against the women, you have no issue with it?

utterances.speaker: KINNEMORE
utterances.sentences: It's an allegation.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: KINNEMORE
utterances.sentences: It has not been proven. And the attorney who brought forth -- brought it forth, she did the same thing to Herman Cain and others --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: KINNEMORE
utterances.sentences: -- Kavanaugh. So she is not valid --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: KINNEMORE
utterances.sentences: -- as far as I'm concerned.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: All right. Marcelo, you look -- are you having an issue with that?MARCELO SALVATIERRA, RETIRED SOFTWARE SALES EXECUTIVE, SEN. WARNOCK AND GOV. KEMP SUPPORTER:  Well, yes. I guess if we go back to the very basic comparison between the two character -- between the two candidates, to me, the contrast is significant and easy to see. One, Warnock -- Sen. Warnock seems to me to be a very good individual -- honest. Christian, as somebody mentioned earlier. And I have some serious concerns with Herschel Walker's character -- like, his honesty. His approach to family life. So, clearly, from my perspective, I view Walker as a flawed candidate. And unfortunately, the Republican Party has done a disservice to the people of Georgia by putting forth that kind of a candidate. I voted for Kemp. I was more than willing to listen and see if they had put forth a viable, credible candidate on the -- for senator -- but they did not. So, ultimately, for me, the decision was easy. And clearly, it was based on character. Character matters, qualifications matter, and I don't see Walker as having any of those.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Robert, you're raising your hand.

utterances.speaker: SCHOFER
utterances.sentences: Yes, I would like to opine on the far-left comment. Our president is not a far-left, he's a centrist, and he's not an extremist. Let's just go with a centrist. And to have somebody who doesn't even live in Georgia trying to run for a position in the state of Georgia, I find that appalling in itself. He's a resident of Texas. What's he running in Georgia for?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.Scottie, you have been awfully quiet, so I want to hear what you have to say about this. What do you say? They say he's a resident and not of Georgia. You're a supporter. What do you think? SCOTTIE DENNIS JR., LANDSCAPER, HERSCHEL WALKER SUPPORTER:  Well, I am not 100 percent aware that Herschel Walker is still a Texas resident. I know that he lived there prior to living in Georgia. But I believe that Herschel Walker meets the qualifications to run here. But I'm definitely voting for Walker because unlike Sen. Warnock, Walker has been very clear on his positions regarding the issues. If you watched the debate between Walker and Warnock, Warnock would not answer any questions directly. He just kind of danced around them like a typical politician. And for him to only be in the Senate for one year that's pretty remarkable that he's able to do that. And I just don't think that we need to have six more years of Raphael Warnock in the U.S. Senate, especially as a pastor who openly supports things that are contradictory to the Bible that you're supposed to be preaching every Sunday.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Charles, I want to hear more from you because you're an undecided voter. How are you going to pick in just these last few days here?CHARLES SCOTT, BUSINESS OWNER, UNDECIDED IN Senate RUNOFF:  I'm a business owner. I am kind of worried about my business and how it thrives. And then on the flip side, I'm also a minority. That actually, some of the -- some of the things that happens to minorities, I feel kind of strong that those things need to be taken care of, too. So it's kind of a catch-22. So I just kind of want to do -- I feel like maybe I needed to do a little bit more research on Walker and Warnock to see what are they going to do for the people instead of just for their side.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Are you leaning a certain way?

utterances.speaker: SCOTT
utterances.sentences: I'm not for sure.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: You're not for sure?

utterances.speaker: SCOTT
utterances.sentences: I'm not for sure.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Not for sure. Are you just being coy with us because you don't want us to know? I mean, you've had a lot of time to make up your mind.

utterances.speaker: SCOTT
utterances.sentences: Yes, sort of -- sort of. I mean, like I said, originally, I did vote for -- I voted for Warnock. But like I said, Herschel Walker has some points that benefit me, too.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: SCOTT
utterances.sentences: So that's the catch-22.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: How many of you believe your candidate is going to win?(All hands raised except Scott and Schofer) That's -- you don't believe Warnock's going to win, Robert? Were you not raising your hand and I just didn't see it?

utterances.speaker: SCHOFER
utterances.sentences: I -- no, I am very pessimistic. I think it's -- we keep saying we're a blue state and the numbers are showing that we're not a blue state.

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: I loved that.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. You did? Why?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I loved that. I told you -- I said sometimes it's hard on tape -- you know, like -- I wanted more from them.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I loved it because you know what? They -- one woman said to you -- well, you know, I think she's pro-life and she essentially said but I'm voting for Warnock because I believe that he supports giving sort of more resources to people that maybe they will choose to have the child. I think she saw some nuance to it and she reflected what we often ask lawmakers about. Really interesting.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: It's -- as you know, you covered these issues there.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: She was just there.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: These issues are more nuanced than many times people --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- especially people who are so entrenched in politics and many times as portrayed in the media. It's very nuanced and people are not always so far left and so far right. They have some issues -- they have some values and things that are important to them that are conservative, and some that are maybe more liberal.

utterances.speaker: KAITLAN COLLINS, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And it's not -- they're just not so polarized.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: That's why it's always so great to hear from them directly.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Because these things that we talk about and these big views when we talk to lawmakers, listen to them there -- they just -- voters can so simply just distill, like, their thinking on something.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: And no I can't. This is how I feel.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. And just so you --

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: It's not complicated.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And just so you know, by the way, we had to cut it down for time for television, right, so I'm -- you know, I'm just -- and I'm just really happy that they were able to share --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- their views because we wanted a lot -- to hear a lot more from them.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And they spoke to us for quite some time.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.And obviously, don't forget to join us for the Georgia runoff between Raphael Warnock, the senator, and Herschel Walker, his Republican challenger. That's on Tuesday and our coverage will start on Tuesday at 4:00 p.m. eastern.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: That's going to be interesting.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I really actually -- I'm looking forward to this one. Usually, I'm like oh my gosh. This one, I'm looking forward to. It's going to be --

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes, it will be fascinating.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. COLLINS

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Plus, star soccer player Christian Pulisic speaking to the media for the first time since his game-winning goal sent Team USA to the knockout round.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: It's not just the years, honey, it's the miles. Well, it's been many years since Harrison Ford said those words as Indiana Jones in "Raiders of the Lost Ark" -- more than 40. And thank goodness, now the fifth installment of the franchise "Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny" is heading to theaters next summer. And we just got our first look at the teaser trailer. Here is it.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) Clip from "Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny." (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: All right. So, what do we know -- which I'm trying to explain this graphic here. The new installment mostly takes place -- OK, it takes place in 1969. The first "Raiders of the Lost Ark" was set in 1936 but the film opens in 1944.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: All right. They used the aging technology to have Indy fighting Nazis in a castle.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Sorry.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: You got that?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Wait, wait, wait. Indy?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Is that what they call him?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Indy -- Indiana Jones, I guess -- yes.So -- oh, they make him younger. We're -- I was wondering this morning when we discussed this on our editorial calls, can they do that for us? Is there a de-aging setting --

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Us?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Well --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- in the control room?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You well know how young you look.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: (Laughing).

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You do not need that filter.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: They take the tape off afterwards. No -- I -- no, you don't need it either.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Of course, Kaitlan doesn't --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thanks.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- need it at all.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: That makes me think of that --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Indy.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: -- quote that we had last week when he was with Walter Mondale on the debate stage --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Oh --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: What'd he say?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: -- and they were asking if he was too old. And he was like I'm not going to take advantage of my opponent's youth.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Of your youth and inexperience.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: That's so true.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: All right. Speaking of youth, Team USA's soccer coach, Gregg Berhalter, is now saying that Christian Pulisic is on track to play in the team's match against the Netherlands. This is crucial. His return was in jeopardy after he suffered a pelvic contusion. Remember, he scored the game-winning goal, putting his body on the line against Iran this week.And now, for the first time since he was injured, Pulisic took questions from the media about how he's doing. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: REPORTER
utterances.sentences: What did it feel to you now that you have that forever moment.

utterances.speaker: PULISIC
utterances.sentences: It feels great to score in a World Cup. Timmy knows what that's like. I think -- I'm hoping I haven't had that moment yet, to be honest. I'm hoping it's in front of me. So it feels great to be where we're at right now, but there's still more to come.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Can you talk about yesterday's Germany-Costa Rica game with a big milestone not in terms of the players but in terms of the ref -- an all-female referee crew? I just wonder what it was like for you to see that.

utterances.speaker: FOUDY
utterances.sentences: Oh, a long time coming, Poppy -- yes. A little bit overdue for sure. But the fact that you had three women reffing that game.Stephanie Frappart, who is one of the legendary female refs, took the lead officiating position. She's done World Cup qualifiers before. She's done Champions League before. But she had never -- no female has ever reffed a men's World Cup game and she was the first. She has a lot of firsts in her career. And the fact that it was in Qatar, which, as we know, their issues with women's rights and their suppression of women's rights is front and center at this World Cup. It was a big step I think for a lot of men and women to see.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Have you -- you've been paying -- you mentioned women's rights. A lot has been paid this time to just rights in general for these games.Is it -- is it taking a bigger -- is it a bigger priority, you think, this time than any time, or is it always an issue in these games?

utterances.speaker: FOUDY
utterances.sentences: Don, you cut out a little bit there. What was the -- what was the first part of it you said?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I said that rights have really taken a priority role -- a big role --

utterances.speaker: FOUDY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- in the games this time. And is it always this way because it seems like there -- it's playing out more and I'm not sure if it has to do with the venue or just the times --

utterances.speaker: FOUDY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- that we're in, or maybe it's a combination.

utterances.speaker: FOUDY
utterances.sentences: I think World Cups are always a microcosm of what's happening in life. But the fact that it's taking place in Qatar with all the controversy around the bid, around the setting, having to switch to the wintertime from the summer because of the heat, the fact that it's shown that obviously, there were some nefarious things that were happening behind the scenes with this bid. And obviously, their human rights issues with migrant worker abuse, and all of the things we've been talking about.You've also seen -- I mean, there's been so much drama on the field, as we know, which has been crazy. It's hard to be a productive human with all this World Cup going on. But you also know that there's been drama happening off the field as well. People coming into stadiums not able to wear shirts, for example, that have rainbow flags on them, or as we've seen with the players unable to wear the armbands with the rainbow insignia. So, yes, this is -- this is one that I think actually has been talked about more because of the fact that it's in Qatar.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Absolutely.You talked about it interfering with the work schedule. At least tomorrow's game is going to be on a Saturday -- HARLOW:  I don't know why (PH).

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: -- when we will be watching it at 10Julie, thank you so much for joining us.

utterances.speaker: FOUDY
utterances.sentences: No worries. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Two-time FIFA Women's World champ.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: And gold -- Olympic gold medalist.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes, just that. Quite a career.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: No big deal.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Julie, thank you.All right, so big thing overnight -- strike averted. The Senate passed legislation to keep rail workers on the job. Ahead we're going to be joined by a railroad way mechanic who says the Biden administration sold him out.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Welcome back to CNN THIS MORNING.Two Aurora police officers are being hailed as heroes for going beyond the call of duty by jumping into a frozen pond to rescue a 9-year-old little boy who had fallen through the ice trying to retrieve his football. Our Adrienne Broaddus has the story. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: DISPATCHER
utterances.sentences: 9-1-1. What's the address of your emergency?

utterances.speaker: CALLER
utterances.sentences: We have a person drowning.

utterances.speaker: DISPATCHER
utterances.sentences: Drowning? Where?ADRIENNE BROADDUS, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over):  It was the day before Thanksgiving.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Water rescue, we have a 9-year-old that's fallen in the water and they're not able to get out.BROADDUS (voice-over):  Tyshaun (PH) is the 9-year-old who fell through the ice.

utterances.speaker: MARY WILKINS, MOTHER
utterances.sentences: I think about my --BROADDUS (voice-over):  Tyshaun's mom, Mary Wilkins, was at work.

utterances.speaker: WILKINS
utterances.sentences: I was so scared. And then when I got that call from them saying he was not responding and stuff, my mind was gone.BROADDUS (voice-over):  Aurora police responding with water rescue kits.

utterances.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
utterances.sentences: Give that to him.BROADDUS (voice-over):  Officers Andrew Soderlund and Alex Lopez --

utterances.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
utterances.sentences: Right there.BROADDUS (voice-over):  -- didn't think twice about entering the water.

utterances.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
utterances.sentences: Pull, pull.

utterances.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
utterances.sentences: Come on, let's go.BROADDUS (voice-over):  The child and an adult who tried to rescue him exhausted.

utterances.speaker: OFFICER ANDREW SODERLUND, AURORA POLICE DEPARTMENT
utterances.sentences: The winter coats that they were wearing -- you know, that became very heavy for everybody.BROADDUS (voice-over):  Then, finally --

utterances.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
utterances.sentences: Yes, we got him out of the water.BROADDUS (voice-over):  Tyshaun and the officers a little bruised.

utterances.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
utterances.sentences: Take his clothes off him.

utterances.speaker: OFFICER ALEX LOPEZ
utterances.sentences: He has bumps, bruises -- a lot of kind of scrapes and stuff from breaking the ice. I lost my wedding ring in the pond as well.

utterances.speaker: WILKINS
utterances.sentences: And I thought my baby was not going to be here. And I'm thankful for him.BROADDUS (voice-over):  Thankful to spend another holiday with her son and grateful for the officers who didn't hesitate.

utterances.speaker: WILKINS
utterances.sentences: I'm very excited and nervous. I can't wait to meet these people.BROADDUS (voice-over):  And when expressing gratitude --

utterances.speaker: WILKINS
utterances.sentences: My name is Mary.

utterances.speaker: LOPEZ
utterances.sentences: Hello.

utterances.speaker: WILKINS
utterances.sentences: Thank you so much for saving him.

utterances.speaker: LOPEZ
utterances.sentences: Of course, of course.BROADDUS (voice-over):  -- sometimes a hug --

utterances.speaker: WILKINS
utterances.sentences: Thank you.BROADDUS (voice-over):  -- says it best.

utterances.speaker: SONDERLUND
utterances.sentences: Of course. How are you?

utterances.speaker: TYSHAUN
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: WILKINS
utterances.sentences: Thank you so much.

utterances.speaker: LOPEZ
utterances.sentences: Of course, of course.

utterances.speaker: SONDERLUND
utterances.sentences: Thank you so much.BROADDUS (voice-over):  Adrienne Broaddus, CNN, Chicago.

utterances.speaker: SONDERLUND
utterances.sentences: I'm glad everything turned out OK.

utterances.speaker: WILKINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.
